title: HW0 Q3
content: Problem Context:This is another review problem that is just there to help you bring some classic material back into your memory. You'll need facility with this --- moving to SVD coordinates, etc. --- to understand key ideas in the course.
document:
Problem Context:

This is another review problem that is just there to help you bring some classic material back into your memory. You'll need facility with this --- moving to SVD coordinates, etc. --- to understand key ideas in the course.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Can we assume our matrix X is full rank (for part a)?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Can we assume our matrix X is full rank (for part a)?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Yes, the matrix $X$ is full rank. Do you see why?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Yes, the matrix $X$ is full rank. Do you see why?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The problem guarantees that all the singular values of X are nonzero üëç. Thanks for the help!</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: The problem guarantees that all the singular values of X are nonzero üëç. Thanks for the help!

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Any advice on how to do D differently from A? I'm not sure how to minimize while also finding a way to use the Xw = y equation.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Any advice on how to do D differently from A? I'm not sure how to minimize while also finding a way to use the Xw = y equation.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Xw = y is not necessarily true for A. This is because X is a linear transformation from R^n onto R^m, where m > n, so it will cover only a subspace of R^m. If y is outside the Col(X), then Xw won't be equal to y. </paragraph><paragraph>I think it's helpful to remember any formulas associated with the minimization problem described in the beginning -- answering this might help answering both A and D parts.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Xw = y is not necessarily true for A. This is because X is a linear transformation from R^n onto R^m, where m > n, so it will cover only a subspace of R^m. If y is outside the Col(X), then Xw won't be equal to y. 

I think it's helpful to remember any formulas associated with the minimization problem described in the beginning -- answering this might help answering both A and D parts.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Do we need to use Lagrangian multipliers in order to solve (d)?</paragraph></document>
comments.document: Do we need to use Lagrangian multipliers in order to solve (d)?

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>You <italic>can</italic> use Lagrangian multipliers to solve (d). However, there is a simpler way. Recall how the minimum norm solution was derived in previous classes (e.g., EECS 127).<break/><break/>A hint: Think about the set of solutions for an underdetermined system. How can you use that to inform yourself when deriving the optimal $\mathbf{w}$?<break/><break/>Feel free to ask again if you're unsure how to proceed.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document:
You can use Lagrangian multipliers to solve (d). However, there is a simpler way. Recall how the minimum norm solution was derived in previous classes (e.g., EECS 127).

A hint: Think about the set of solutions for an underdetermined system. How can you use that to inform yourself when deriving the optimal $\mathbf{w}$?

Feel free to ask again if you're unsure how to proceed.
